This is a set of clips to add a Plexiglas/Acrylic front door on your PowerSpec 3D X Dual Extruder Printer, FlashForge Creator X, or any other 3D printer with a 13.750" wide by 8.375" front hole. The plywood front is called 1/4" but technically measures 5.2mm (13/64") and the clips were sized to fit snugly. When printing ABS or Nylon, you need to remove drafts and control the temperature of the build environment. Adding the front door is one part of doing that. It also helps to keep the printer clean when it is not being used. The door clips are tight enough to fit and hold themselves on the printer, but are easily removed if desired. The door should be made of 1/8" thick Plexiglas (clear acrylic) available from the hardware store for a couple of dollars. Glass size: 9.5" x 15" The glass easily slides in and out from the top. It cuts down on noise coming out of the printer too. Let me know your results and if you find any other printers that these clips fit.

description.text: Concept by Colin J. Roberts and Paul J. Roberts. Please see their website for more information and history: http://www.pjroberts.com/sphericon/index.php Some have two positions. In the picture see the amusing paths that these objects (the ones without "Stop" in the filename) will roll along. 3D Modeled by Chris K. Palmer Printed by Jeff Rutzky. See his model in action here: http://www.vimeo.com/16985828 I uploaded these with Paul's permission to commemorate the arrival of my Cupcake CNC!

The HexaSphericon was successfully printed on a CupCake CNC by Jeff Rutzky. He put 3mm rare earth magnets into it to allow for the two parts to be put together into all the possible positions. All the uploaded models have the small square holes like the rendering of the part with the bottom side up and visible shows to receive 3mm rare earth magnets.
The models with "Stop" in the file name will not have a continuous roll path like the ones in the rendering but instead will roll until hitting a stop flat spot. The rendering without paths shows some but not all of the other Sphericons with stops as well as the ones without stops.

This technique might also work with ABS using acetone, too.

A cheap monitor stand to clear up space on the desk taken by the stands.
The height and width is easily adjusted by using different length profiles.
The desk lamp was also attached to the frame to remove the large round base.

I had two Omnimount CL-S wall mounts. I bought a third for â‚¬35 new. They allow great flexibility as well as pivoting. Two clamps used to hold a vice to a desk (â‚¬5 each), fix the frame to the desk. The aluminium profiles (30x30 8 mm slot) came from Motedis.de:
2x1000 mm
2x500 mm
2x300 mm
  • Print two strong and six light angles.
  • Drill 8 mm holes 15 mm from the end of the 300 and the 500 mm profiles.
  • Use four self tapping screws to assemble the frame except fot the lower horizontal bar (see rendering).
  • Reinforce the corners using the angle brackets.
  • Attach the monitor arms to the frame.
  • Clamp frame to desk (I stuck self-adhesive "feet" under the frame to protect the desk).
  • Wire everything (I have a usb hub attached to the frame)
  • Attach monitors
    (9.) Optionally attach Artemide lamp with the lamp clamp
    • The total cost without the arms came to about â‚¬50. I may design some cable holders to replace the cable-ties, but I can't see them so they don't bother me.

Quand on a sous la main la collection de toutes les « Ball Top Seimitsu » et qu'on se dit que c'est trop bête de ranger celles dont on ne se sert pas sur les sticks de la borne, on imagine alors une sorte de présentoir percé de vis bien alignées, sur lesquelles on viendrait visser les boules, juste comme ça, pour faire joli…
http://burogu.makotoworkshop.org/index.php?post/2014/09/03/presentoirballstick

• L'impression doit donc être faite en disposant l'objet en diagonale dans un carré de 194x194mm.
    Avec les quatre fichiers STL que j'ai généré, rien à faire, chaque objet est déjà placé dans la diagonale.
    Rien de spécial à dire sur les réglages d'impression…
    Mais une précaution à prendre, pour décoller les objets de la surface d'impression : attendre le refroidissement complet !
  • Les trucs imprimés c'est bien, mais l'aspect de surface n'est pas jolie. De plus, forcements la jointure entre les deux parties est très visible, donc après avoir collé les deux parties à la cyanolite, allons-y pour un masticage en règle, avec du mastic standard de marque Sintofer.
    Puis étape de ponçage, avec du papier abrasif 400 et de l'eau, ça évite d'avoir de la poussière partout et rend le ponçage plus doux.
    Ensuite une sous-couche blanche à la bombe avant de peindre l'ensemble.
  • Le câblage des LEDs peut être facilement calculé à l'aide de cet outil en ligne très pratique, sachant que le montage sera alimenté par le 12V provenant de la borne.
    Ici sont câblés en parallèle 3 lots de 3 LEDs en série, chacun protégés par une résistance de 120Ω.
    Les câbles sont placés dans la gorge et les pattes des LEDs replié dans celle-ci, pour qu'à la fermeture de la glissière elles soient en appuie à la bonne hauteur pour éclairer la boule.

remixed_from.title: The Orange Screamer - A wide-area annoyance device

title: The Original Orange Screamer Keychain with Snap Fitting and Solidworks 2014 source
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mix mash between two different makes.
First this is the original AndyGadget's version http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:455093 that I made the source for but then I saw DanielStein's version @ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:479357 and loved his take on it. Well, his is larger than the original one to accommodate his snapping mechanism so I decided to give it a whirl myself. I kept the dimensions of the original and just added the snapping together mechanism. You may glue it or just snap it and, as I said, this still has all of the holes, and pegs, of the original.

From the original I repost his instructions - The rotor sits on the spindle and then the lid is glued on with cyanoacrylate adhesive. However, you will get best performance if you slightly sand the parts in contact to get rid of any roughness left from the printing. A few drops of light oil in the works before gluing will help things too. Reducing friction is the name of the game.
,
This version allows snapping them together so you may do it that way or to increase the bond you may glue it as well.

remixed_from.author: BonsaiBrain
remixed_from.title: parametric universal heavy duty 20ml syringe extruder

title: 60ml Syringe Extruder for Liquid Deposition Modeling - LDM
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Updated version of our experimental syringe extruder, it is designed for a 60ml syringe which is the perfect dimension for our printing need. The syringe model is a luer lock type, which means you can use a lot of different nozzles from the luer lock system.
The extruder is designed for a 3Drag printer (K8200), but you can easily adapt it to other system by designing a customized mount for your machine. 3Drag is a moving bed machine, so the extruder is still during the print without any issue of moving weight. If you use this on other printer models remember to slow down all head movements like print speed, travel speed etc.
The gear reduction ratio is 5:1, which is enough for printing in clay, but not enough for more viscous materials. This ratio has been decided for dimensional constraints of 3Drag printer, but for other machines a 6:1 or 7:1 ratio it is recommended.
-For the main body we had to design a very big part, around 30cm in lenght. In the next future the main part splitted in 2 smaller parts will be provided in order to be printable with all most common FDM machines.

you will need:
-3Drag printer (https://www.futurashop.it/3d-e-cnc/stampanti-3d/stampanti-3d-1/3drag-stampante-3d-versione-1.2-in-kit-7350-3dragk)
-6x 30mm M3 bolts and nut
-2x 20mm M3 bolts and nuts
-1x M8x170mm rod
-1x M8 nut
-1x 608zz bearing
-2x C profile 133mm (6x6x1 thichness)
-4x diam 3mm x 15mm long self tapping screw
-a lot of Inj/Light 60ml Luer Lock (http://www.doctorshop.it/Prodotti/Siringa-INJ-LIGHT-latex-free-a-3-pezzi-da-60-ml-cono-luer-lock-senza-ago-6400048)
-For setting up the printer you have to determine the right E-step for your extrusion stepper (our value is 12500 steps for 1 mm of filament).
Slow down your extrusion speed around 0,5mm/s, and try to extrude 10mm of material. Measure the movement on the syringe, and solve this formula:
NewEstep = OldEstep x NominalDistance (extruded from software) / MeasuredDistance (real movement)
Set the new E-step and repeat the procedure. Once you are near to right value try with bigger extrusion distance like 50mm or 100mm to make a more precise calibration.
-In the slicer software you just have to set:
Filament diameter to 29mm (inner diameter of the syringe)
Nozzle size around to 2mm (you can change it a little on the real value)
-Check if you have enough material for the print, in Cura you can see how many meters you are using for the print. The syringe is long around 100mm, so you can use 0,1m maximum

We made an upgrade to the cooling fan (for faster drying).
We have placed 2x 60mm 12V big fans on the backside of the extruder, with an external power supply, and that switch is to activate the fans.
We don't use them in any print, because a faster drying means a more stable print, but also a higher risk of shrinkage cracking (in clay prints).
So just don't care about that switch :)

comments.author: piuLAB

comments.text:
The fracture were on one of the thicker point of the main body, and crossfiber. We think that it were just a bad print, but we noticed that we have a uneven stress distribution, so we prefere to just redesign the part.
We usually don't do FEM analysis because it can't calculate fiber orientation, emptiness, printing defects and surface quality. It's almost useless. We just design the part thinking we're working with plywood, with fiber plane parallel to printing plate

We made it share-alike as any of our project because we believe in the Open-Hardware comunity as a wonderful way to make improvement in 3D Printing, we made it non-commercial because we are happy if you print our extruder and you use it as you like. If you are planning to manufacture our extruder and sell it as if it was your work we're not as happy because we spent many days designing it.
If you want to sell it make your extruder model and sell your work not the work of others :)
On the other hand, if you want to sell the models you printed with our extruder i don't think there are any restrictions.

You can create a chicken watering system for your flock when you combine these parts with chicken nipples, PVC pipe, clear vinyl tubing and a water container.

description.header: The 3D printed parts of this system are:
description.text:
• A bulkhead fitting (I think that is what it's called) for making a water tight connection to a water container with a 1/4" vinyl tube.
  • A connector for a connecting the vinyl tube to a PVC pipe.
  • Some brackets for suspending the pipe using chains or wires.

    This is for a gravity fed system. The fittings should not be used under pressure. Print the parts at 100%. I did that by slicing it with 10 loops and the parts came out strong.

    Additional parts you'll need:

  • Piece of 3/4" PVC pipe
  • PVC endcap
  • 3/4" PVC male adapter
  • Several feet of clear vinyl tubing with an inside diameter of 1/4"
  • Some chain or wire to suspend the waterer
  • Chicken nipples
  • Water container (like an empty 5 gallon bucket).
  • 2 or 3 rubber washers (the size used with a garden hose)

• Cut the 3/4" PVC pipe to the length you need. I spaced out the nipples 6" apart and used 3 nipples. I left 3" of pipe on each end for the fittings. I cut the pipe to 18" long (3" + 6" + 6" + 3") .
  • Measure and mark the locations of the nipples on the pipe.
  • Drill and attach the nipples to the pipe using instructions provided with the nipples.
  • Glue the end cap on the pipe.
  • Glue the male adapter on the other end.
  • Insert your printed non-threaded adapter into the printed large nut.
  • Put a washer on the end of the male PVC adapter.
  • Screw the nut (with the non-threaded barbed adapter on it) onto the male PVC adapter. If it does not fit tight enough, you may need to place an additional washer onto the end of the barbed adapter before inserting it into the nut.
  • Drill a hole in your water container the smallest size that'll let you still insert the threaded-barbed-adapter through it.
  • Put a washer on the adapter. Insert it though the hole you drilled and carefully tighten the nut on the other side.
  • Connect the clear vinyl tube to both barbed fittings.
  • Squeeze one of the printed brackets onto each end of the pipe.

description.text: A minor modification that will make a world of difference to the accuracy and endurance of your 3D printer.  This is also the easiest way to level your printer bed by simply filing down the PB-Y axis bar mounts on the high side of your bed.  An easy print for beginners because all the settings are in the Gcode.  I have printed these and use them on my bot.

The standard lasercut wood for the Printrbot Y-Axis bar mounts, and the Y-Axis belt clips, are cut to very tight tolerances that will, over time, start to scrape against the Y-Axis 10 tooth pulley gear under the bed. This will cause minor problems with your 3D prints by producing circles with a slight oblong shape, or faulty perimeters with stray filament strands and this can leave you with unusable parts. In addition, the lack of room will leave you trying to level your printer bed by spending extra money on springs, grommets or washers, when all you need to do is file down the bar mounts on the high side of your printer bed. Leveling can be completed for both the X and Y axes with this one print. If accuracy and endurance are vital to your prints, then this enhancement will make a huge difference for being such a minor mod. I use the Printrbot Plus, but I know this will work with all current models of Printrbot and the files have been optimized to print on either the 6 inch or 8 inch Printrbots. The Gcode file was created using Slic3r 0.9.7, regardless of the Printrbot model you have, just download the Gcode and go. This is a mod of the original Printrbot files posted by Brook Drumm: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16990 The details of this mod are as follows: 1) Raises the bed just 3mm by making the PB-Y bar mounts 3mm taller.
2) Makes the PB-Y bar mounts 3mm wider for a better grip on the Y axis rods.
3) Makes the belt clip base 3mm thicker so the Y axis belt can be properly aligned for the Y axis pulley and belt guide.
4) Includes the Y Axis stop screw hole.
5) All files associated are configured for ABS plastic.
6) The Gcode file is centered on X: 75 Y: 75 for either the 6 inch or 8 inch Printrbot models.
7) This is a great print for beginners. Just download the Gcode and print. All the settings you need are in the Gcode. All you need to do is calibrate all your axes first. It is best to print all these parts at the same time because both the Y bar mounts, and the belt clips, work together as a package. If you leave the old belt clips in place, and use only the Y bar mounts, then the belt will not align to the Y axis belt guide, and vice versa. The STL file has been cleaned and optimized using Netfabb and is ready for your Slic3r. Once your printer is calibrated, level and ready for long enduring prints, please take a look at my 10 tooth pulley mod for both the X and Y axis motors. I added a slot for the 3mm nut that came with your Printrbot and this makes for a very tight fit to the stepper motor shaft. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:48672 If you have any questions, please ask below. Thank you,
Tom Heibel
Sticky Pod

description.text:
For those who like the years 70,80 and 90.
Robots Vintages

An application of the design concept behind the Heptagonal Column ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:482 ) to a standard Clark Y airfoil. Like the column, this assumes that Skeinforge will print the zero thickness faces with enough flexibility to support bending/folding there. This is an experiment and I would be surprised if some adjustments weren't required... EDIT: Nophead pointed out that, in fact, zero thickness faces don't print out. Luckily, this is easily fixable since the big, flat underside can be adjusted handily with a push-pull or extrude command in most CAD programs. Here's an example of that: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:485 EDIT2: Jay Swift had a brainwave and pointed out that you could print this out on a flexible sheet of plastic. This is brilliant, because the sheet would replace the zero thickness face on the bottom. You would just have to trim the sheet before you rolled it up.
Print it out, roll it up, voila! Wing section. :-)

During the build of my Huxley, i found that the x-axis was quite complicated compared to Prusa's Mendel. This is my take on his work to suit Huxley. These two parts replace the 12 needed for the origional x axis (plus 10 bearings!). I also took inspiration from MarcusWolschon; I shelled the majority of the bulk so it can be filled with casting resin. This is due to be built on a Stratysis Dimension FDM printer so i have not optimised it for a support-less build; I will do so in the future. This has not yet been printed, i will edit later and let you know of my great success/failure! Follow my build log on: http://strelly3d.blogspot.com EDIT: Just optimised it slightly. Reduced build volume by around 7 ccm and hopefully it should be printable on a reprap now.

comments.author: syncra

comments.text: Yea, you only need these two to hold the x-axis. The vertical hole acts like a bushing, mine printed out indersized too (not used to designing with RP in mind!). The lead screw is very much derived from Prusa's; the idea is to wedge a nut in the bottom hex slot, and compress a spring in the large hex slot, and put another nut in place. See http://reprap.org/mediawiki/images/e/e2/AssemblingDarwinMachinery-28.JPGhttp://reprap.org/mediawiki/im...
comments.author: syncra

comments.text: Many thanks, very useful information - now I think I understand. May ask where and what spring did you buy?  It would make my life easier as I did not think about this springy backlash system!
comments.author: strelly

comments.text: I did indeed plan to use springs, but i found that if i assemble the x-axis without them (still keeping the two nuts on each lead screw) there is no backlash. I wanted to avoid using the springs if possible as it only increases the friction, but it is still early days so i may be wrong!

author: hamza

title: Da Vinci 2.0 Rear mount cooling fan shroud

description.text:
UPDATE. I actually don't like this thing anymore. It kept getting caught on the screws on the back of the bed. So I have made a better design that attaches to the front. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:553792 This fan shroud will attach to the back of the Da Vinci 2.0 tool head. This is for the Dual Fan model. It redirects air from the second fan to cool the extruded plastic. Please note that repurposing one of the two fans does reduce the cooling to the extruders. I am working on another fan shroud to address that problem.
I recommend you use custom firmware to control the fan that you attach this to. See the instructions for more information.
I lowered the aim of the left nozzle.10/6/2014 It was too high.

I modeled this part myself using Blender.
Print the model standing straight up without any support. I have tried using ABS and t-glase (PETT). The t-glase printed fine but it warped after a few minutes of use. I suspect PLA will warp the same way. ABS seems to work just fine.
In order to mount the fan shroud you need to bend the metal fan mount to be at a right angle. I did this to make it easier to design. It also makes this part compatible with the new Internal fan shroud that I am working on. I will post that new thing soon when I can test it some more.
You will also want to turn the fan around so that it will push air into this shroud rather than pull air through it.
In order to control the fan via software you will want to follow instructions found in this web forum. http://voltivo.com/forum/davinci-firmware/239-cooling-fans-for-extruded-plastic-and-the-tool-head

title: Pop Shield with Brauner Phantom C Mount

description.text:
I went to buy a pop shield and the only ones available were Â£70!
Cue me designing this one.
It's not the most elegant design but it serves its purpose.
Yes, the mount is for a Brauner Phantom C but the mount is separate to the pop shield so have fun designing your own mounts.

The mount and the ring can be printed as normal. You may need to trim the corners / sides of the peg to fit the hole in the mount. FYI I printed at 0.3mm layer height. The actual pop shield uses Slic3r's infill to create the mesh. Set Slic3r to:
Minimum 8 perimeters (for a nice think border)
Infill = 0.2
Solid layers top = 0, bottom = 0
In advanced, if you have anything other than 0 in "Infill" and "First Layer" then make sure these match so the infill lines up. I used 125% in both for my print. I haven't yet experimented with the different types of infill, they could make for some different visual patterns and possibly different pop stopping abilities.

author: Red_sonya

title: CubeX External Spool Holder with Filament guide

description.text:
Please excuse the pictures of the object - my power "flickered" just as the print was in its last phase, and the CubeX couldn't retrieve the information from where it left off. You can see it can hang off the front of the printer, but it can actually hang on any side of the CubeX since the spool's rod is parallel to any side it hangs from. Coupled with the filament guide, the system provides minimal resistance when the gears in the print head pull the filament. The object functionally hangs, and the filament guide would have turned out just fine. The cardboard cubify cartridge spool fits on the spool rod with room for smaller spools too.
This model is a remix of this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:401979
It is meant to hold a spool off the back of the CubeX, using a bulk filament spool that has an overall diameter of 225mm (aka, the distance between the spool rod and the wall of the CubeX will be 112.5 mm).
The remix includes a more compact and filleted design, and an added filament guide so that the filament can enter the print jet from an angle (about 40 degrees from the horizontal) as opposed to from a 0 degree angle.
The holes in the design are meant to save filament and weight.
NOTE: top cover of the CubeX printer must be OFF to use this
Any and all feedback welcome.
Can be printed without support. Printed with a 25% infill (using KISSlicer).

remixed_from.author: peacefrog
remixed_from.title: Instant Platform adjustment just add 3 nuts to each screw

title: XY Leveling Gears for the Instant Platform Adjuster

description.text:
This Thing is a gear (I printed four at a time using Skeinforge's multiply - 2x2 array) for placing over the middle nut suggested in Peacefrog's Instant Platform Adjuster.  
With a gear over each middle nut, it was a breeze to level out my build platform.

• Print 4x XY leveling gears.
  • Install the bolt upside down in the wooden support platform.
  • Tighten bolt down with one nut.
  • Place another nut over the first.
  • Place an XY leveling gear over the second nut.
  • Repeat for other three corners.
  • Replace the build surface.
  • Install build platform and dial the gears to the proper levels.
  • Place a nut on top of each exposed bolt.

comments.text: Mine came out a little ugly ( I haven't really dialed my machine in yet), but perfectly useable.  I force-fit the nut into the top of the object with the handle of a screwdriver. Thanks for a great hack!

author: Dynamic

title: Heavy Duty Herringbone Gears for M8  or 9/16 (14mm) Bolts

description.text:
8/10/17
I ran the 9/16 (14mm) version through netfabb and rolled the gear by 180 degrees. Sorry about that, but the original printed just fine. 7/9/17
This update is long over due. I included a gear for those eBay sellers passing 9/16 bolts as M8s! Also, I increased the axle distance to fit more custom wade designs. 9/30/14
I decided to replace my gears, but couldn't find ones with a gear ratio other than the stock 47:9 gears. I found thicker gears for Prusas, but because they use different hobbed bolts, they weren't physically compatible with my extruder. Even after tinkering with washers/spacers, I had X carriage clearance issues.
So I made my own herringbone gears with a 37:13 gear ratio. These gears are direct replacements for stock gears, but more durable.
They're perfect for those with dual extruder setups.
WARNING: even though they're direct replacements, you still need to modify your firmware! You need to change the E steps in your configuration marlin file. Change E to "424", compile, then upload to TAZ.
DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {X,Y,Z,424}
If you don't change your firmware, these gears will not work!
Also, make sure to read the instructions!

Print settings:
*PLA only
layer height: .2 mm
infill: 50%
print speed: drop down to 70%
I don't like loose herring bone gears, so I made everything tight! Make sure to lower your speed settings to improve accuracy.
0)When slicing, make sure the area for the captured nuts faces up. You may have to rotate your z axis by 180 degrees to achieve this. If you don't do this, you may have aligning issues with your hobbed bolt.
1)Drive the hobbed bolt deep into the larger gear to ensure its grinding area aligns properly with the hole on the extruder. You shouldn't need more than 3 washers, depending on your extruder.
2)Install small gear on the shaft of your stepper motor. But first, make sure to drive a small drill bit into the hole of the smaller gear to clear any print imperfections. The smaller gear should rotate very slightly around the shaft of the stepper motor.
3)Install large gear alongside the smaller gear and tighten hobbed bolt with all bearings and washers. Once the large gear has been installed across your extruder, rotate the large gear several times to properly align the small gear. After aligning both gears, tighten the little hex screw on your small gear to secure the gear tightly.
3)Once the two gears have been installed, eliminate all play between the two gears by pushing the stepper motor inward, and tightening the 3 screws found on your motor mount area.
Both gears should rotate easily, free of wobbles and/or resistance.
4) make sure to open your marlin configuration file and recompile your program with the updated E parameters for your E variable (change stock 800 to 424).

The original Thing was made for a laser cutter and since I don't have one I generated three things that can be printed without support and glued together. You are of course encouraged to cut out whatever letter you want from the center of the head board (I used a "V").
V2 now includes the engravings on the Head board, Foot board and Side boards as well as the OpenSCAD source files. Now it works with the Customizer since I combined all the OpenSCAD source files into one.

I downloaded the SVG file and opened it in Inkscape. I selected each object and exported the path to an OpenSCAD source file (3mm thick) using the Inkscape to OpenSCAD plugin (available here on Thingiverse). I then used OpenSCAD to reassemble the bed from the five parts and exported this as an STL file. This I loaded into netfabb Basic and cut it along the z-axis such that the bottom portion was cut in half, 1.5 mm for the bottom, 1.5 mm for the top. The bottom part was rotated 180° on the y-axis and saved. The top part was cut at the x=0 plane and each part was rotated for easy printing without support and then saved as STL files. I then created a new FreeCAD project and loaded in the three STL files and positioned them as a single printing plate. I then used Inkscape to create an artistic letter V and again exported the path to an OpenSCAD script which was then compiled and saved as an STL file. The "V.stl" file was then also loaded into FreeCAD. The Head board object and the V object were then converted into solid objects, the V was positioned in the proper location and then subtracted from the Head board object. This was then saved as the STL file to slice and print. Here I have included the separate files.
With V2 I have added all the source files plus my print plate with the "V" cutout of the headboard.

remixed_from.title: Stepper upgrade for makerbot MK5 extruder

title: Stepper upgrade for Kysan DC extruders

description.text:
Design is currently untested! I decided to release it early. This is a simplified version of thing #4824. I took out the stem of it so the stepper hangs off the other side of the extruder. This means you only need one extra 606 bearing. It also means a lot less wasted plastic.
Also, instead of a NEMA 17 mount, I changed the mounting pattern to be for the Kysan gearmotor so that you can use this upgrade on a MK3, MK4, MK5, or Brutstruder. I will be using this with a Brutstruder so that's the main thing I'm designing this for. There actually probably won't be enough clearance to use this with a MK4 so I'm going to recommend using this with a Brut or MK5.

Print out a gearedsteppermount.stl, a small.stl from thing 4824, and a large.stl from thing 4824.
Attach stepper to plate with M3x8mm (?) bolts. Attach gears to stepper and M6 bolt according to directions on thing #4824. Attach plate to brut with M3x35mm bolts and nuts.

comments.text: I'm a bit confused by this.  Is it for a stepper or the Kysan.  If it's for the Kysan, what purpose does it solve?  If I read it correctly, it allows one to hook up the standard Mk3 - Mk5 motor in a Mk3 - Mk5, which we can do by default.  Or am I missing something?
comments.author: randyy

comments.text: it looks like you need the small and large gear from thing 4824.  Then instead of the adapter having a nema 17 mounting hole like thing 4824, it can fit in the kysan hole pattern.  The back of the stepper would be to the left of the extruder body, If I understand it correctly so you can use it on brut/mk3/mk4 whereas 4824 can only be used with the mk5 that has the nema17 holes pre drilled.
comments.author: randyy

comments.text: That makes sense now,  I see it.  Thanks (though it looks like Beak is right that the dinos would be in the way on a Mk 4).  Since that's what I have, I'll look for a different solution.

Yazzo is a system of interconnecting pieces that allow you to create Yazzums (a thing created with Yazzos).  The little pieces are called Yazzettes, and are the individual pieces, such as connectors, panels, and the like.  This thing is simply a few of the connectors.  The OpenScad file allows you to parameterize these connectors, and create any sizes you might want to play with.

description.text:
Nothing super special, just a nice little bin.
I have grander ambitions to make these in various complementary sizes and shapes, add divider features, make a toolbox system that works with them, etc. While I get around to doing any of those things, however, this is a nice busykeeper for when I'm not quite ready for the printer to print something else.

Print! I've used ABS so far but they'll probably work with anything. 
0 extra shells needed.
Fill is mostly irrelevant; it only does any fill in the inside fillet region that joins the walls to the bottom and a little at the top stiffener lip. 25% is fine, 10% or 100% probably okay too.

comments.text: This bin is perfect. The resizing you can do makes this model very versatile. Well done.

description.text:
The file provided is with new supports after the last one I printed. I printed it on a printerbot simple wood. There was support needed in certain areas and removed due to cleanup issues.  
I intended it to fit over my 6g tunnel plugs, which they do, perfectly even, but they are a little too heavy from the very VERY first fairy model I made. I'd say wear it as a necklace or just use as a charm on something.   
Also, the uploaded file is altered a little on the wings, bust, and buttocks to help print cleaner and better with the supports. I want to print another and will share a new picture at that time. Thank you and enjoy!

Ok, so this fairy has a long travel history. I started with splines in MAX, lofted them, then a meshsmooth modifier and collapsed, I then threw her into ZBrush, sculpted her muscles and other printable details. Back then, she had a lot of holes and was way off on scale. Had something to do with the conversion between some very old software packages. Anyways...  
I still printed her and she made it through the print with a lot of problems. Then the boyfriend continued to suggest trying design and meshmixer, so in she went to design. Rescaled in design and then put into meshmixer and yet again gave her an overhaul on sculpting. Now I wear her whenever I want, yet again she was a bit heavy on my lobe during the trip to the grocery. Plan to start from scratch on the next fairy I make. This model has just been through too many versions already.

description.text:
This is the NEW 3D parts composing the V1.2 gimbal of Glimo. It features all functions of the 1.0 version but uses 2 lasse ball bearings and is a little more compact. This gimbal was created to fit on a 20 mm aluminium tube, any other diametre would need modifications.
It is build with 4 universal skate/roller bearings and aluminium spacers (for rollerblade wheels) and two central d25 x D37 x h7 mm.
Find more installation and operating instructions on Instructables :
http://www.instructables.com/member/GlimoTuto
And follow the Indiegogo campaign right here :
http://igg.me/at/Glimo/x/8351860 I'm still working on few other improvements such as a lead adjustable counterweight and a GoPro version
